description:
Aliiroseovarius pelagivivens is a species of bacterium that belongs to the family Rhodobacteraceae. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and chemoheterotrophic organism. Aliiroseovarius pelagivivens was first isolated from seawater samples collected from the Pacific Ocean.

This bacterium is characterized by its ability to produce pink-pigmented colonies, which is likely due to the presence of carotenoid pigments. It is considered a marine bacterium, as it is capable of growing in the presence of high concentrations of sodium chloride. Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Aliiroseovarius pelagivivens is closely related to other members of the genus Aliiroseovarius, which are known to be widely distributed in marine environments.

Further studies on the physiology, metabolism, and ecological roles of Aliiroseovarius pelagivivens can contribute to a better understanding of the diversity and functional significance of bacterial communities in the open ocean environments.
